introduction.openingText: 2024 was marked by biodiversity challenges, but tiger conservation witnessed tangible, heartening progress. The recovery of tiger populations offers a rare beacon of optimism. Tiger conservation successes are a testament to the critical role of Indigenous Peoples and local communities, whose knowledge, stewardship and active involvement in conservation efforts are irreplaceable.

milestones.title: Tiger Conservation Coalition Formed
milestones.description: WWF joined forces with 9 other leading international organizations, marking a new era of collaboration among groups that were once competitors. This represents a groundbreaking partnership in tiger conservation.

milestones.title: $1 Billion Commitment for Tiger Conservation
milestones.description: At the Sustainable Finance for Tiger Landscapes Conference hosted by the Royal Government of Bhutan, partners committed to collectively mobilizing an additional $1 billion for tiger conservation over the next ten years, known as the 'Paro Statement'.

countryTrends.notes: Amur tigers expanding to new territories
Largest tiger population continues to grow
Significant recovery in Western Forest Complex

expandRange.intro: This section highlights efforts to extend tiger populations into new and historic territories, demonstrating that with proper planning, habitat restoration, and community engagement, tigers can reclaim landscapes they once roamed.

stories.title: Kazakhstan Tiger Reintroduction - Historic Achievement
stories.description: In a historic moment, two captive Amur tigers named Bodhana and Kuma were translocated from the Anna Paulowna Sanctuary in the Netherlands to Kazakhstan's Ile-Balkhash Nature Reserve. These are the first tigers in Kazakhstan in over 70 years, having gone extinct in the 1950s. Released into a semi-natural enclosure in September 2024, by February 2025 the tigers had started mating.
keyFacts: Project began in 2018 with ambitious goals to restore tigers to historic range
Six years spent restoring the reserve: reforested more than 120 acres with native trees
Reintroduced prey species including Bukhara deer and Asiatic wild ass
At least 8 more tigers expected to join in coming years
WWF and partners worked with the Auyldastar community over six years
Community-managed compensation scheme being established
Response team in place to manage potential human-tiger conflict

quote.text: This is not just about bringing back tigers. It's about restoring an entire ecosystem and creating a model for coexistence between wildlife and local communities.
quote.author: Conservation Team Lead
quote.title: WWF Kazakhstan

stories.title: China - Amur Tigers Moving to New Frontiers
stories.description: In late 2024, a tiger was recorded in the Changbai Mountains, approximately 200 km south of Laoyeling and the Northeast Tiger and Leopard National Park. This marked the first Amur tiger in Changbaishan Biosphere Reserve since 1994, ending a 30-year hiatus. The discovery was made through ranger-identified footprints and subsequent camera trap footage.
keyFacts: Northeast Tiger and Leopard National Park pilot construction began in 2017
Located in southern Laoyeling, at the border of Jilin and Heilongjiang provinces
Laoyeling region is the only area with a breeding population
Demonstrates success of habitat protection and restoration initiatives
Amur tigers continue to move to new frontiers within WWF priority landscapes

stories.title: Thailand - Historic Return to Mae Ping Forest Complex
stories.description: In October 2022, camera traps recorded the first tiger in more than a decade in Mae Ping Forest Complex, located less than 100 km north of Western Forest Complex. The two complexes are linked by forest corridors. In 2024, WWF Thailand initiated a comprehensive project to determine distribution and abundance of tigers and their prey, establish camera trap-based wildlife monitoring, build ranger capacity, and engage communities.
keyFacts: Aligns with Thailand's 12-year National Tiger Action Plan
Builds on WWF-Thailand's success in Western Forest Complex
Represents hope that tigers are naturally dispersing to reclaim historic habitats
Increased patrolling efficiency through ranger training
Community engagement through conservation and awareness raising

statistics.label: Mae Ping - Years Since Last Tiger

stories.title: Laos - National Tiger Recovery Action Plan
stories.description: In August 2024, the Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry and WWF Laos announced the 2025-2035 National Tiger Recovery Action Plan. While wild tiger populations in Laos are functionally extinct, this plan aims to restore and protect tiger populations through strategies for managing and monitoring tiger populations and exploring the feasibility of reintroducing tigers to natural habitats.
keyFacts: First meeting held in Vientiane on August 15-16, 2024
Participants included provincial forestry officials, law enforcement agencies, and international conservation organizations
10-year plan from 2025-2035
Focus on restoration and protection strategies
Exploring feasibility of tiger reintroduction

secureHabitat.intro: Wildlife corridors are essential for tiger survival, allowing populations to move between protected areas, find mates, and maintain genetic diversity. This section focuses on maintaining and creating these vital connections.

stories.title: Nepal - Someshwor Corridor Success
stories.description: The Someshwor corridor, a vital transboundary corridor located in the buffer zone of Chitwan National Park adjacent to Valmiki Tiger Reserve in India, has shown remarkable tiger population growth. From just 3 tigers in 2018 to 8 tigers in the 2022 National Tiger Survey, recent monitoring has confirmed 14 Royal Bengal tigers in the area.
keyFacts: Located south of Madi Valley where the hill of Someshwor forms the border with India
Facilitates movement of endangered tigers and other species between Nepal's Chitwan and India's Valmiki Tiger Reserve
Nepal's overall tiger population nearly tripled: 121 tigers (2009) to 355 tigers (2022)
Conservation focus shifting to improving habitat connectivity and enhancing coexistence with humans
Monitoring tiger movements and genetic status across the landscape
Implementing landscape-level management plans
Engaging with transboundary partners

stories.title: India-Nepal Transboundary Corridors
stories.description: The Terai Arc Landscape covers 74,097 km² of transboundary territory and supports an estimated 1,000 tigers. This landscape consists of 7 corridors and 3 bottlenecks that facilitate connectivity between protected areas on both sides of the India-Nepal border. Key corridors include the Khata Forest Conservation Area (a critical 15-mile pathway connecting Nepal's Bardia National Park and India's Katarniaghat Wildlife Sanctuary) and the Shikaribas corridor.
keyFacts: Khata Forest Conservation Area received Conservation Excellence Award
Chitwan-Parsa-Valmiki Complex holds approximately 141 tigers, 697+ rhinoceros, and 50+ migrating elephants
Shikaribas corridor connects all three protected areas in southern part of complex
WWF Nepal and WWF India collaborate on increasing corridor functionality
Supports spectacular array of wildlife beyond tigers

stories.title: India - WWF Conservation Efforts
stories.description: WWF-India monitors and supports tiger monitoring in 20 Protected Areas and Forest Divisions across six conservation landscapes. This comprehensive approach focuses on corridor functionality and connectivity to ensure tiger populations can thrive and expand throughout India's diverse ecosystems.
keyFacts: Works across six conservation landscapes
Monitors 20 Protected Areas and Forest Divisions
Focus on corridor functionality and connectivity
Comprehensive landscape-level approach
India hosts the largest tiger population globally

rangerGap.studyTitle: Insufficient numbers and poor working conditions for rangers protecting tigers

endExploitation.intro: Despite conservation successes, tigers remain threatened by poaching and illegal wildlife trade. This section addresses efforts to combat wildlife crime, strengthen enforcement, and reduce demand for tiger parts.

stories.title: Strengthening Anti-Poaching Networks
stories.description: WWF continues to work with governments and partners to strengthen anti-poaching efforts through improved law enforcement, ranger training, and intelligence sharing networks. These efforts are critical to protecting tiger populations from exploitation.
keyFacts: Enhanced ranger training and equipment
Intelligence sharing across borders
Improved law enforcement capacity
Community-based monitoring systems
Technology deployment for patrol efficiency

stories.title: Combating Wildlife Trafficking
stories.description: Working with TRAFFIC and other partners, WWF supports efforts to disrupt wildlife trafficking networks, strengthen legal frameworks, and reduce demand for tiger parts through behavior change campaigns.
keyFacts: Disrupting trafficking networks through intelligence operations
Strengthening legal frameworks and penalties
Behavior change campaigns to reduce demand
Collaboration with law enforcement agencies
Training customs officials for detection

coexistence.intro: As tiger populations grow and expand into new areas, managing human-tiger conflict becomes increasingly critical. The Conflict to Coexistence (C2C) framework provides a pathway for communities and tigers to thrive together.

c2cFramework.description: The Conflict to Coexistence (C2C) framework provides methodology for developing tailor-made human-wildlife conflict management strategies based on local cultural, environmental and social context. The approach emphasizes preventive measures and community engagement.

stories.title: Nepal - Behaviour Change Communication Champions
stories.description: In 2024, Nepal mobilized 114 Behaviour Change Communication Champions who organized 216 local actions, directly engaging 7,656 people. These champions work with herders, women, landless communities, and Community Forest Coordination Committees to design and conduct localized campaigns emphasizing preventive measures for human-wildlife conflict.
keyFacts: 114 Champions mobilized across communities
216 local actions organized in 2024
7,656 people directly engaged
Target audiences include herders, women, landless communities
Focus on community-specific preventive messaging
Working with Community Forest Coordination Committees

stories.title: China - Hunchun Pilot Project
stories.location: Hunchun, Northeast China Tiger and Leopard National Park
stories.description: Launched in July 2024, this pilot project addresses increasing human-wildlife conflict issues in the Hunchun region, particularly damage caused by wild pigs to crops. The project represents the first implementation of the C2C approach in the Chinese context.
keyFacts: Launched July 2024
First C2C implementation in Chinese context
Addresses crop damage from wild pigs
Located in Northeast China Tiger and Leopard National Park
Developing locally appropriate conflict management strategies

stories.title: Thailand - Mae Ping Community Collaboration
stories.description: During 2024, WWF Thailand worked closely with 12 local communities, enabling camera trap deployment that confirmed tiger presence. The C2C strategy is being piloted in five districts outside protected areas, with support for improving livestock pastures and other preventive measures.
keyFacts: Collaboration with 12 local communities
Camera trap deployment enabled by community support
C2C piloted in 5 districts outside protected areas
Improving livestock pastures to reduce conflict
Community-based monitoring systems established

stories.title: Kazakhstan - Proactive Conflict Management
stories.description: As part of the tiger reintroduction program, Kazakhstan has established community-based conflict management approaches including a community-managed compensation scheme and a response team to manage potential human-tiger conflict. This proactive approach aims to prevent conflicts before tiger populations fully establish.
keyFacts: Community-managed compensation scheme in development
Response team formed for rapid conflict resolution
Proactive approach implemented before population establishes
Six years of community engagement and preparation
Integration with tiger reintroduction program

conclusion.lookingForward: The recovery of tiger populations offers hope, but challenges remain. Tigers still occupy less than 8% of their historic range, and significant range loss continues. Only through sustained commitment, adequate funding, strong partnerships with Indigenous Peoples and local communities, and continued focus on habitat connectivity and coexistence can we ensure that tiger populations not only survive but thrive in the decades to come.

closingQuote.text: Only together can we recover and sustain tiger populations that co-exist with people in thriving ecosystems. The future of tigers depends on elevating our partnerships with Indigenous Peoples and local communities, whose knowledge and stewardship are irreplaceable.
closingQuote.author: WWF Tigers Alive Initiative

commitments: $1 billion in funding mobilized over the next decade (Paro Statement)
Addressing the critical shortage of 12,500 rangers in tiger protected areas
Expanding the Conflict to Coexistence framework to all tiger range countries
Strengthening transboundary cooperation and corridor connectivity
Supporting Indigenous Peoples and local communities as essential conservation partners
Continuing anti-poaching efforts and combating wildlife trafficking
Exploring tiger reintroduction opportunities in historic range areas

footer.organizationInfo: WWF is one of the world's largest and most respected independent conservation organizations, with over 5 million supporters and a global network active in over 100 countries.
